THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: THE GERMAN EMPEROR.
div.p: We do not wonder at the enthusiasm with which all Germans celebrated their Emperor's silver wedding yesterday. Few monarchs have. deserved better of their country than the Emperor, and if his people just now are inclined to mark the anniversaries of his birth and marriage with an especial warmth they have reason enough for their inclination. Fortune and a matured and brilliant stroke of policy have raised him within the past twelve month' to what is scarcely less than the dictatorship of Europe. His Majesty at this moment holds a position of actual and potential power almost Napoleonic in its range and effectiveness Carlyle long ago declared that Europe by, Sedan had exchanged a mistress for a master. His words have come true, and if the German people are thrilled by the evidences of their truth with a new exaltation, with a supreme consciousness of being on the crest of the rising wave, and with a fresh and zealous pride in their ruler, who shall blame them ?

Popular estimates of heirs-apparent are rarely worth much. Even if they were their usefulness would still be limited ; for the weight of a crown, the sudden change in duties, surroundings, advisers, and interests radically modify | h e character. History is foil of instances where men were one thing as Crown Princes and quite another as Kings. It is, therefore, nothing strange that William II. should seem to-day a totally different being from the youth whose abrupt accession eighteen years ago to the most powerful throne in Europe sent a shiver of alarm from London to Moscow. The alarm • was not unnatural. The coolest headed states. men shared it. At the time nothing else seemed possible. Both as Prince William and as Crown Prince the present Emperor had done nothing to reconcile foreign Powers to the idea of his new position. Royal rhetoricians are usually disquieting, and the young Prince haul net only genuine powers of declamation which he seemed only too anxious to show off, but he invariably chose the most disturbing of all topics on which to exercise them. The world had no option but to catch the rattling of the sabre and the beat of the war drum through all his impetuous periods. The uneasiness redoubled during the brief and pitiful tragedy of his father's reign. The Crown Prince appeared to sink the son too much in the coming Emperor. He should have kept in the background; instead, he took every opportunity of posing before the people in full pageantry of war. He might at least have held his tongue; instead, his speeches multiplied in vehemence and fervid imagery. Europe found it hard to forgive his struttings and line-light effects. It wrote him down as a rather self-willed and theatrical youth, consumed with Chauvinism, and lending himself with an avidity that seemed more French than German to the easy histrionics of militarism. Wherever he went the full stage effects of a regimental setting went with him. Whenever he spoke it was in flaming apostrophe of the sword and martial glory and he heroic deeds of the most warlike of his ancestors. It was inevitable that the world should see in him little more than a prancing German edition' of Harry Hotspur, dashing, heady, with an instinct for flashy and inopportune display, and terribly given to sounding the charge.

‘To do the big thing in the big way." That, one is convinced, is the direction in which the balance of the Emperor's nature overwhelmingly inclines. He is a man who may be touched on many sides, whom things stir quickly and strongly. Above the fundamental bent towards whatever is clean, manly, and above board, above the range of glowing sympathies, there is his strong imaginative, aid yet stronger dramatic, sense to appeal to. No one manages to throw scab feeling into little international courtesies His telegrams of condolence to the widows of Marshals MaoMahon and Canrobart were, in' their way, quite perfect. He has something, perhaps a good deal, of the Crusader temperament. He is profoundly moved by tales of heroism, by the clash and jar of elemental life, and he has himself set an example of triumph over disabilities that does not fall below the heroic level. His left arm, AS everyone knows, has from his birth been practically useless. He has met the affliction by training the right arm to do the work of two- an easy feat to record, not so easy to accomplish. Many men simply throw up the race on smaller pretexts than that, and a King who had not the right fibre in him would be peculiarly seduced into making himself out a martyr of circumstances. The Emperor has never been one of that kind. So far from sitting down under his handicap, he rose to conquer it. In his list of accomplishments there is a guarantees of something more than mere versatility, and more even than a liking for the wholesome, manly things of life: there is proof of so immense strength and discipline of character, energy, will power, and of that “infinite capacity for taking pains” which, if it be not genius, is at least as solid a foundation as one could wish for any head of a State. Look at it which ever way you please, it takes a man to win such a match with Fate as that. No weakling could have done it; no one with any SERIOUS FLAW IN HIS character could have done it.

div.p: The Seudan Government has reduced the duty on gum from P.T. 65 to P.T. 60 per kan'at

div.head: Back from the Yemen.
div.p: An Ottoman »ti am»r arrived at Suez on Thursday with 500 sick and wounded Turkish troops on board on their return from the Yemen. On its arrival the steamer paid the Canal dues and on Friday proceeded to Constantinople.

div.head: Khedivial Decoration.
div.p: An application has been made to the American Senate by Mr. Secretary Root to authorize him to deliver the decoration of the Order of the Osmanieh of the third class, conferred by the Khedive on Mr. Bthelbert Watts, Consul General at St. Petersburg.

div.head: British Club, Alexandria.
div.p: The alterations to and famishing of this Club are nearly complete and the house committee have decided to have the formal opening on Saturday,' the 10th march, when they will hold a reception from 6 to 9 p.m., to which, members and their friends (including ladies) will welcomed.

div.head: Army of Occupation,
div.p: Capt. and Brevet Major A. R. Hoskins, D.8.O., North Staffordshire Regiment, has arrived in Cairo and has assumed his duties as Deputy Assistant Adjutant General (Major General Staff), in that Command. Major A. H. C. Kenney Herbert, Northamptom-hire Regiment, Deputy Aesistant Quartermaster General (Major, General Staff),has cease duty, on being relieved by Major A.R. Hoskins, D S O.

div.head: Arabic at Cambridge.
div.p: The representations of Lord Cromer and the Foreign Office, which have led to the drawing np of the report of the Special Board for Oriental Studies, recommending the abandonment of Greek and Latin in the examination of Asiatic and African students, and the substitution of English for one language and Arabic, Chinese, or Sanskrit for the other, will, it is feared, lead to the settlement of the ‘Greek Question” at Cambridge by instalments.

div.head: Port Said Developmeent
div.p: The new Banded Store and Transit Ware¬house now being constructed at the rear of the Navy House is nearing completion and will be ready for me during April next. As the whose of the necessary formalities in future will begin and end on the spot, including the payment of duty, the Customs staff of this district is to be augmented, and the different offices will be provided to form a Sub Custom House under the direction of Hassan Bakery Eff., late of the Alexandria Custom House, an energetic officer

div.head: Egyptian Geography
div.p: A new edition of Mr. H. W. Mardon’s useful little work on the geography of Egypt and the Anglo Egyptian Sudan has made its appear¬ance. It has been increased by twenty pages and is very up-to date. This little text-book has been prepared mainly to meet the needs of Egyptian schools, but it contains great deal of valuable information, and visitors to Egypt will find it a very handy book of reference for there is a great deal to be learnt from it which cannot be found in guide-books. The publishers are Messrs. Blackie and Son, Limited, of London.

div.head: Cairo "Zoo".
div.p: The Zoological Gardens at Ghizeh, Cairo, have just received a valuable and interesting present from the Government of India con¬sisting of two specimens of the Langur, or Hanuman, the sacred monkey of the Hindoos, and a beautiful collection of birds, including six species which have not been better exhibited in the Ghizeh Gardens, namely, the Indian Adjutant bud, a gigantic species of stork ; the black necked ibis, the I v y scarlet ibis from tropical America, the Bur¬mese peafowl, the Sarus crane, and the wonderful crowned pigeon from New Guinea.

div.head: A Story from Kharotoum
div.p: The third day a party flourists were visit¬ing the Mahdi's and Khalifa’s capital, and were taken over the public school, where some hundred and fifty boys and girls were being instructed in arithmetic, grammar, foreign languages and all the other knowledge which is supposed to develop and elevate the youthful mind. The party was shown over the school by a British official, who has laboured most energetically and most successfully in what may be regarded as a somewhat ungrateful task. He was accompanied on his tour of inspec¬tion by a Pasha who had served as an officer in the Mahdi’s army, who in the old regime had been eminent as a slave-trader, and who on the fall of the Khalifa had thrown in his lot with the British, and who had been promoted to high rank as a faithful adherent of British rule, end a sincere convert to British ideas. When the inspection was over the Pasha asked his British colleague what the school cost. He was informed that in round numbers the cost was £5' 0 a year. On hearing this the veteran slave-dealer said, with a sigh, “To think that only a dozen years ago you or I could have brought the whole lot, toys and girls, for £50,”

div.head: "THERE WON'T BE WAR" AN INTERVIEW IN PARIS. GERMAN OFFICIAL’S PACIFICATORY ASSURANCES. ( Gazette's Special Service.)
div.p: Semi-official journals in Vienna agree in stating that the Vienna Cabinet his taken steps at Berlin to induce Germany to meet the French demands in regard to the police question at the Algeciras Conference.

The ‘ Gil Bias” of Paris to-day publishes an interview which if has had with the secretary to the German Ambassador in Paris, who said that Europe desired peace and that the Kaiser shared this sentiment. Germany was ready to support pacific aspirations by making concessions in regard to the policing of Morocco. Summing up, he said that there would not be war.

div.head: RUSSIAN GOVERNMENT CRISIS. COUNT WITTE'S FALL PREDICTED. (Gazette’s Special Service.)
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph’s” correspondent at St. Petersburg states that the crisis in the Russian Government is becoming more and more acute. Prominent officials predict that Count Witte’s fall is not far distant

div.head: RUSSIA’S GOLD PAYMENTS. (.Gazette’* Special Service.)
div.p: The statement that Russia intends suspending her gold payments is denied in to-day’s "Daily Telegraph.”

div.head: NELSON’S FAMOUS MEMORANDUM ( Gazette's Special Service. )
div.p: The original draft, in Nelson’s own handwriting, of his famous "General Memorandum,” issued to his captains at Trafalgar, which comprises eight large quarto pages, and recently came to light after a concealment of a hundred years, will be offered fur auction at Christie’s on March 14.

div.head: The Frontier Question
div.p: The two delegates of the Sublime Ottoman Porte who have been sent to Egypt to discuss the Akaba frontier difficulty, arrived at Alex¬andria on Saturday. They are Miralai Ahmed Muzafiar Bey and Bimbashi Mohamad Fehmy Bev, both of the Ottoman General Staff They have proceeded to Cairo and are the guests of the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner.

div.head: Mr. Bryce and the Armenians
div.p: A meeting of the Armenians of Alexandria was held on Thursday last under the presidency of Bishop Daniel, at which it was resolved to despatch a telegram to the Rt. Hon. James Bryce on the occasion of the banquet given in his honor r on Friday by the Armenians of London. The following telegram was therefore lent on Friday :—
Right Honorable James Bryce, Westminster Palace Hotel, London.
Armenians at Alexandria mooting in Tigran Yergat Union Hall express deep gratitude for your sincere efforts towards the relief of the oppressed Armenians. —For the Committee, BISHOP DANIEL.
Another meeting was held yesterday at the issue of which the following telegram was despatched to President Roosevelt.
President Roosevelt, Washington

Armenians at Alexandria meeting church resolved to join their wishes to the voice of European Armenophiles, soliciting your influential intervention for the relief of their countrymen, suffering under the Turkish misrule.—President of the meeting, BISHOP DANIEL.

div.head: The Sucrecries Bairam Bey' Conclusions Must Go Into Liquidation
div.p: Saturday’s hearing of the Sucreries case proved interesting enough after a banal opening Me. Carton de Wiart having demanded the approval by the Tribunal of the settlement arranged by the company and the majority of its creditors, and given a number of cogent reasons for its approval, Me. Padoa Bey wished to make certain observations, but the Court finally ruled that Bairam Bey, who represented the Government, should speak first. Bairam Bey then rose and gave his conclusions as to the granting of the concordat, which may be summarized as follows. 1

The approval of a concordat preventif, even though voted for by all the creditors could only be granted by a Court if the debtor had been unfortunate, i.e , had suffered from causes over which he had no control and of good faith. In this case the debtor was a fictitious person —a joint-stock company - and there could be no question of good or bad faith in connection therewith. The Sucreries Company qua company was an abstrac¬tion ; who personified it ? Its administrators or its shareholders in general meeting! The text of the law now in force and European.* precedents left no doubt that the administra¬tors alone were capable of legally representing this fictitious personality.

In this particular case the administrators had paid dividends from the profits of secret and at first successful speculation. It had accepted M. Cromer’s bills and had increased its expenditure at a time when its factories were working at a loss. The drawing of a distinction between the members of the board who were responsible for these proceedings and those who were ignorant of them should not influence the Court. Members of the board who were kept in ignorance of the truth should have insisted on verifying the accounts sub¬mitted to them and insisted before the respon¬sible parties on their undoubted rights. Moreover, the board, on the collective principle, was an undivided legal personality, and no distinction could be drawn between its mem¬bers. Therefore, as the board was a personality and had not acted in good faith, nor been unfortunate it must go into liquidation.

After some discussion as to whether Me. Carton de Wiart as counsel for the party interested could reply to the Attorney General, represented by Bairam Bey, the Court ad¬journed Judgment will be given on March 8,

div.head: Eqyptian Constructions L.D.
div.p: The subscription list of this Dew company was opened this morning at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank and its branches. We are informed that by Boon to-day the issue had beau applied for over three times.

div.head: Signor Serator's Last Concert
div.p: Signor Serato and Mme. Malatesta gave their farewell concert at the Savoy on Friday, and in spite of a somewhat thin audience, owing no doubt to the second day’s racing at Ghezireh, both the celebrated violinist and his most efficient accompanist outvied all their previous successes. Signor Serato’s rendering of Veracini’s sonata was beautiful in the extreme, but never has he been heard to such good effect as in Max-Bruchs concerto in sol minors. The Adagio movement in special, with its plaintive melody, could not have been given with more fine feeling and purity of expression. The Rondo brillante of Schubert’s was also a treat for the musical and those not so highly gifted, and as an encore he gave a well-known Polonaise of Vicuxtomps’ which was absolutely masterly in its treatment. Mure. Malatesta, gave two solos, that delightfully quiet and simple Albumblatt fur Elise of Beethoven’s, and Chopin's Polonaise la bornolle maggiore, which is such an absolute contrast and which gave Mme. Malatesta every opportunity to display her undoubted mastery of her instrument.

It is much to be regretted that this is the last occasion this season that we shall I hear these two musicians, who have made such a success for themselves, but we trust; that Signor Serato’s coming season in London will add fresh laurels to his reputation.

div.head: Cairo Corso;Well-Designed Cars; Description of the Procession
div.p: Carnival has suddenly burst forth in virulent form and the street’s of Cairo yesterday were filled with streams of overladen carriages and b 'By onlookers, and on every side were seen pedestrians jigging along in fantastic attire, and the toot of the tin and paper trumpets were heard in all directions. Very soon after lunch there was a general exodus in the direc¬tion of Ghezreh and many fearfully and wonderfully decorated cars were to be seen in the procession. A huge sun helmet formed the canopy over an equally enormous up-side down straw hat wherein sat a collection of the typical tourists, blue-veiled, blue spectacled, and attired after the fashion of Caran D'Arche. Then again followed a windmill fashioned of pink satin and gaily decorated with crimson flowers wherein was ensconced a fair incognita. A ponderous fort on wheels was peopled with a host of sailorboys, another car supported a enormous crescent moon from which peeped out a motley crowd of Pierrota, a scarlet figure sitting astride of a cask in front of it. Another CAT represented an elephantine typewriter, and , yet another illustrated the sad fate and punish meet doe to speculations various stuffed figures hanging from the gallows upon it A massive boat contained another crew of Bailors who spent their spare time singing to the light guitar, while just behind them followed on a troupe of Japanese in fan decked carriage canopied by a wide spreading umbrella.

It was impossible to keep count of all that passed, and it there were many fewer folk upon the stands the crowd on foot was far thicker than it was the preceding Sunday. The Ghezreh Palace was crowded during the afternoon and teas were served for over two thousand people, and this number could have been only the smaller half of those who were on the grounds. The drive home even was a matter of difficulty, and the crowd of onlookers at the fur her end of the bridge was almost as dense as that upon the course. Naturally the English contingent was in the minority, but these who were there appeared to be enjoying themselves, and a fair number of those who stayed away were inclined after¬wards to regret the fact.

div.head: The Austrian-Hungarian Ball; Remarkable Display of Jewels
div.p: Never this season has there been such a collection of decorations worn by the gentlemen, or so many beautiful frocks and wonderful jewels displayed by the ladies, as on the occasion of the Austro-Hungarian ball at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, on Friday last. The ball room was filled with guests of all nationalities and dancing became a matter of great difficulty as the evening wore on. At about half past ten the strains of the Austro-Hungarian nations' anthem announced the arrival of Count Koziehrodsky, Minister of that country, who was accompanied by Count Stadnicky and M. Emilo Charles Welunscheg, secretaries to the Agency, M. de Hahn, and the other members of the Agency and Consulate. It would be impossible to enumerate ail those who were present, but noticeable among the some six hundred guests were Mr. and Countess Valda Machell, M Moise Cattaui Bey, M. and Mme. de la Boaliniere, Princes Louis and Antoine d’Orleans, the Prince of Siam, M. and Mme de Martino Pachs, M. Ferdinand de Martino, Mme de Vrie-, M. Ang. Fatica, Major L’Estrange John¬stone, Boghos Pacha Nubar, M. and Mme Mas- kens, Marquis and Marchioness Salvago-Ragg', Abaci Paoba, M. lgnaoe Ztbrevsky, Miles Anne and Abe Z brevity, Count and Countess de Piccolimci Baron and Baronessde Villebois, Count Zichy, Hon. Mr. Iddings., Hon. F. Morgan, Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Fischer, Count Batthyany, Baron and Baroness de Trautenberg, Countess de Crenville, Baroness Way, Conut Thum, Mr. A.D. Albau, Mr. Sciortino, M. de Goracuchi, Prince Fonad, Marquis Soregna, Mr. and Mrs. Crookshank Pacha, Thurneyasen Pacha, M, Mme and Miles Barois, Omar Bey Sultan, Gene¬ral and Mrs. Bullock, Mile Laure Suares. M. and Mile Prampolini, M. and Mme Giew, Mme. Zuhar

Very beautiful was the dress worn by Mme De Martino Pachs of gold-spangled gauze with pink satin and roses at the corsage. and aiming eyes falored in the wake of Mme de Vries in her wonderfully fitting frock of a thick embroidered crepe de Chine which some said was amber-colored while others declared it pink. On one half of the draped crossover bodice appeared glimpses of diamentee gauze which also showed at the opening of the long tunic skirt. Lady Valda Machell was wearing her wedding dress, a stiff white brocade em-broidered with light sprays of silver, and her jewels included a diamond and ruby tiara and a handsome dog color of pearls with diamond clasps Mrs. Bullock had on a handsome gown of blue brocade with shaded pansies in 'he lace of the corsage. and the Miles. Zebrevsky were much admired in their pretty frocks of spangled gauze Mme. Cattaui was in an empire frock of turquoise chiffon velvet with much heavy metallic tissue on the bodice, and Mrs. Nungovich’s dress of white velvet embroidered with softly glowing beads . of various shaded was finished with tiny revers of pink velvet. As before remarked. the display of jewels was something unique; the value of the pearls alone must have ran into only thousands of pounds, and the diamonds would have ransomed many a king,

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL. INNISKING KILLINGS FAREWELL MIRTH AND SADNESS COMBINED
div.p: There was a note of sadness under the gaiety of Thursday’s dance at Ghezireh Palace Hotel, for the thought was present in the minds of most that it was the last occasion on which the popular officers of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers would make merry within 'hose historic walls. Men may come and men may so, but whoever takes their place it will be a long time before the gallant Inniskillings are forgotten, and there were many, we fancy, who felt that no future could quite make up for the past. It was tactful inspiration that led to the orchestra bursting forth with the strains of "Auld Lang Sync” at the beat of midnight, and one ventures to think that both Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers and Cairo Society will have their thoughts in common whenever they hear those well-known bars again. Naturally there was a big dinner given in honour of the departing guests and many a farewell had to be gone through daring the evening, for part oft he regiment was leaving the following day and time was short and opportunities few.

There were numerous other dinner parties in progress at the same time, for Ghezreh Palace Hotel and the 8avoy run each other hard on the score of popularity and far be it from us to say which is the more favored. Certainly the surroundings and architectural beauties of the former attract many blessed with a sense of the artistic, but then there are solid advantages connected with 'he latter which cannot be gainsaid. Prince Louis and Prince Antoine d’Orleans were among the hosts on Thursday evening, and Col. and Mrs. Gordon, Mr. and Mrs. Hewetson, Capt. Rainsford, Lady Lamnson, Mr. and Mrs. Pepper, Mr. and M-s. Williamson Wilson, Mr. Phillips, and Mrs. Andrews were all entertaining parties of various sizes. Conspicuous among the crowd who afterward is congregated in the large hall and ballroom were the Count and Countess Larsche and Sir James Blythe with his family party consisting of Captain and Mrs. Rome and his pretty unmarried daughters. Major and Mrs. Wynne were also there, the latter wearing a particularly graceful Empire dress, the short bolero edged with a narrow pleating from beneath which flowed the soft and filmy skirt Mrs. Hewetson is one of the lucky few who are always irreproachably gowned, and her black frock molded her beautiful figure to perfection. Mrs. Home too was much admired in her gauzy frock glittering with faint lines of silver sequins, the bolero with its apologies for sleeves being fashioned entirely out of heavy dull silver tissue. Mrs. Smart who brought her young and charming daughter, was wearing a blue chiffon trimmed with lovely lace, and Mrs. Roper, in black with jetted corsage showing folds of golden tissue at the décolletage, was wearing many fine diamonds, notably a diamond snake enrolling her throat. Mrs. And Miss Leveridge were among their friends, the latter wearing a fresh and dainty softly hued muslin, and Mrs. Morgan was in a pretty lace frock adorned with tiny wreaths of chiffon roses. One of the Miss York’s wore an extremely dainty frock of grey moonlight silk with wreaths of very pale pink chiffon roses. Miss Phillips looked her best in a pretty shade of blue with folds of pink and cluster of roses at the décolletage, and Miss Rees was in cream lace with a large bunch of violets in the corsage. Mrs. Hunter was wearing a curious but becoming combination of grey and copner colour, the latter appearing as ceinture and at the neck, and Mrs. Armstrong had on a very handsome grey chiffon velours with applications of dull silver passemanterie on the bodice.

Time forbids a further mention of the many other pretty toilettes present, but among those as yet unmentioned were: ---Capt. And Mrs. Bayley, Dr. and Mrs. Phillips, Major Wynne, Mrs. And Miss Crotton, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dailgeish, Mr. and Mrs. Foeden, Mr. and Mrs. Lesdon, Mrs. Cranston, Lady and Miss Lampson, Miss Ambridge Miss Bontler. Lady and Miss Lampson, Miss Hemming the Misses Coles, Mrs. Allen Joseph, Miss Joseph, Miss Orborne. Major Watson, Major Davidson, Col. And Mrs. Gordon, Lient. Roberson, Lient. Cunningham, Mr. Randolph Berens, the Messrs. Musgrove, Mar. and Mrs. Mitchell Innes, the Hon. G. Morgan, Capt. Morgan, Mr. J. P. Taylor, Dr. Armstrong, Major Pirie, Mr. Curphy, Lady Warner, Mr. Carter Wilson, etc. etc.

div.head: STEAM MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Menepthah sailed from Malta on Saturday afternoon and is due here on Wednesday morning at day break, with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The S.S. Bolderaa and City Dandee (Wescott and Laurance Line) left Malta yesterday and are due here next Wednesday, coming from Antwerp and London.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: T. R. H. the Archduke Joseph and the Archduchess Augusta of Austria are expected to arrive at Alexandria this afternoon by the German steamer.
Lady Cromer, accompanied by the Hon. Evelyn Baring and suite, has gone to Mena House Hotel to-day for a fortnight's stay.

Lord and Lady de Clifford are coming to Egypt again on their honeymoon, which will be spent in Abyssinia, from whence they will return in about six months, their present intention being then to settle down h Ireland.

The Postmaster-General, Saba Pacha, is leaving for Italy on the 21st March in order to attend the Rome Postal Congress, which will meet on the 7th April. This will be the third Congress that Saba Pacha has attended.

We hear that at the next meeting of the Royal 8ociety, which will probably take place in June, the name of Capt. Lyons will be proposed aa a Fellow. 8uoh a proposal implies an acceptance on both sides, and we are sure that all our readers will join ns in congratulat¬ing the head of the Survey Department on so well-deserved a distinction.

A very pleasant and largely-attended reception was held by H. E. Beghos Pacha Nubar and Mme. Nubar at their Cairo residence. The Fitzner quartette played in the evening and Cairo society was very well represented.
Sir Charles Roe, who for many years was on the Bench in the Punjab, is leaving England early in March for Egypt.
The Hon. T. A. Brassey and Lady, ldina Brassey have come to Egypt, where they intend staying about three months.
Colonel H. J. Robinson, Coroner for North East Lancashire, is also coming out to Egypt.
Mrs. W. F. Peel desires to inform her friends who are invited to her daughter’s wedding, that it is ^avoidably postponed until Satur¬day, the 17th March.

div.head: Orbituary
div.p: We deeply regret to announce the death of Mrs. 8tone, the wife of Mr. R. E. Stone, who was for some time sab-u a agar of the Cairo branch of the Bank of Egypt Mrs. Stone was attacked by typhoid fever nearly two months ago and in spite of every attention at length succumbed to the disease at the Anglo-American Hospital, Cairo, at 9 SO a.m. on Saturday. The funeral service took place yesterday at 8.30 p.m. at All Saints’ Church. Many friends of the deceased were present at the service and at the funeral and many beautiful wreaths and flowers were rent. We beg to offer on our own behalf and on behalf of our readers our most sincere and respectful condolences to Mr. Stone and the family and friends of the , deceased on their sad and irreparable bereavement.

div.head: To-Day's Telegrams ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE. STATE BANK SCHEME. SITUATION FURTHER COMPLICATED.
div.p: M. Sooner, speaking in the Chamber, on the subject of Morocco, emphasized the fact that France wants peace, bat peace with safe¬guarding her rights and dignity.
div.note: At this morning’s sitting of the Conference there was no fresh development.
The Moors have submitted a State Bank scheme, which is farther complicating the situation.

div.head: KINO GOING TO BIARRITZ.
div.p: The King goes to Biarritz on the 28 the inst.

div.head: The Sokoto Rising, Cause of Disaster
div.p: Major J. A. Burdon, Resident at Sokoto reports that there is no doubt that 3 British officers and 25 native soldiers have been killed. The disaster is attributed to the horses having bolted and breaking the square. The garrison at Sokoto is safe. The local chiefs are loyally co-operating for the suppression of the rising. Reinforcements are expected at Sokoto on the 28th instant

div.head: RECALCITRANT NATAL CHIEFS.
div.p: Several Natal chiefs, notably Um-Skofeel, have become recalcitrant and have refused to visit Colonel Mackenzie’s headquarters, making trivial excuses. (Later). Um Skofeel has arrived at Colonel Mackenzie’s camp. The tension has been re-lieved.

div.head: TROUBLE IN PEKING. SUPPOSED PALACE QUARREL.
div.p: The Guards around the Forbidden City have been doubled and all the palaces are protected by Special detachments. There is no definitive explanation for this, but it is attri-buted to a palace quarrel regarding the suc¬cession to the throne or to the alarm of the Government in reference to the persistence of revolutionary rumors.

div.head: CHINA AND ENGLAND. JOINT SURVEY OF RAILWAY.
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph” learns from Tokyo that China and England will make a joint survey for the railway between Bhamo (Bur-mah) and Tingyueh (Yunnan). The construction of the line will begin soon.

div.head: THE MONROE DOCTRINE.EFFICIENT ARMY WANTED.
div.p: The Secretary of War advocates the build¬ing up of an efficient army for maintaining the Monroe Doctrine.

div.head: GERMANY AND AMERICA, Commercial Relations
div.p: In consequence of the fruitless Americo-German negotiations to conclude a regular commercial treaty and the unwillingness of America to concede a reduction in her duties, the Reichstag has agreed provisionally to extend the clause of the most-favored Nation treatment for one year, thus averting a tariff war.

div.head: KAISER’S SILVER WEDDING. CELEBRATIONS IN BERLIN.
div.p: The Emperor William’s silver wedding is being brilliantly celebrated here. A deputation of the 1st Dragons has come to present their congratulations and a gift to the Emperor.

div.head: Panic In Martinique; Seismic Disturbances
div.p: According to advices received here, Mont Pelee and La Sonfriere are active. A panic prevails in Martinique. The earthquakes taking place in these islands are the most severe that have occurred for years.

div.head: WOMEN’S FRANCHISE BILL. SIR CIIAS. DILKE’S MEASURE.
div.p: Sir Chas. Dilke’s Women's Franchise Bill provides that every man and woman shall be qualified to vote, and no person shall be dis-qualified by reason of sex or marriage from being a member of either House of Parliament.

div.head: TO IMPROVE PORTSMOUTH DOCKYARD.
div.p: The Admiralty have decided to adopt their predecessors’ scheme for expending £2,000,000 on improving Portsmouth dockyard and enabl¬ing it to deal with the biggest battleships of the Dreadnought class.

div.head: DOUMA ELECTIONS.
div.p: The elections to the Douma in the provinces will take place between the 2ud and 10th April.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL FOOTBALL.
div.p: Rugby. Scotland 13 points. Ireland 6.

div.head: YEMEN RISING. SERIOUS LOSSES OF TURKS.
div.p: It is reported that the Turks have sustained most serious losses and have retreated from Sanaa to Taiz, where fighting continues.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt
div.p: Messieurs lea Actionnaires de la National Bank of Egypt sont convoques en Assemblies Generales Ordinaire et Extraordinaire poor le Samedi 21 Mars 1906 a trois heures et demie de 1'apres-midi, au Siege Social, au Cairo.

Assemblee Ordinaire. Rapport du Conseil d’Administration. Rapport des Censeurs. Approbation des Comptes de l’exerice olos le 31 Decembre 1905. Fixation du dividende. Proposition de reiuction, dans certaines conditions, de la quote-part revenant a la National Bank dans les benifices de l’Agricultoral Bank. Renouvellement partiel da Conseil d’Ad-ministration. Election des Censeurs pour l’exeroice 1906. Fixation de i’indemnite des Censeurs.
Assemble Extraordinaire. Mod fixations aux Statuts : Article 20. "E evation a 22 du nombre maximum des Administrateurs.” Article 22 "Reduction de la duree des fonctions du Gouverneur a cinq ans.”

Tout actionnaire possedant au moins vingt actions a droit de prendre part aux Assem¬blees Generales a condition de deposer ses actions dans l’on des lieux ciapres designes cu il lui sera delivre une carte d’admission.

En Egypte : Cinq jours au moins avant le jour de la reunion, soit le 18 Mars au plus tard : Au Sege Social, au Caire ; a la Succursale d'Alexandric ; aux Agences de la Banque Assiut, Assuan, Benhs, Beui-Suef, Chibin-el- Kom, Damanhur, Fayum, Keneh, Mansurah, Minieh, Port Said, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig et Musky (Caire); a "Anglo Egyptian Bank ; a la Barque Impdriale Ottomane ; au Credit Lyonnais ; a la Bank of Egypt.

div.head: Prospectus
div.p: The Company has been formed for the purpose of {inter alia) carrying on business as Engineers. Contractors and Builders, and the undertaking of irrigation, railway, canal, marine, sewage, and constructional engineering, and public works of all kinds.

In consequence of the growth of the trade and the increase of the wealth in Egypt, and the consequent raising of the standard of living among all classes, and the steady increase in the population, the building industry in Egypt has been extraordinarily active within recent years ; and it is reasonable to suppose that the activity will be at least well maintained, if not increased, in the future. Engineering and building operations of all kinds are in progress throughout the country. Large sums of money are to be expended on public works. Private houses, flats and offices are on all sides being erected, and the demand for snob buildings is ever , increasing.
The following is an extract from the note by the Financial Adviser on the Budget for 1906

‘‘Roughly speaking, it may be said that Egypt, is actually spending from L.E. 300,000 to L.E. 400,000 annually on public buildings ; not, I think, an extravagant sum, having regard to the revenue of the country and the fact that everything has to be provided ab initio, hospitals, post offices, prisons, asylums, schools, police stations, to say nothing of Gouvernorats, and other Government buildings of practically every description.
“Of course in the above figures are not included great works of public utility of a remunerative nature, which are charged to Reserve Fund.”

With the working capital at its command, the Company will be in a position to take full advantage of the increasing prosperity of the country, and to undertake engineering and building contracts of the largest kind. Hitherto it has been found that Where any works of magnitude have been executed in Egypt, the preponderance of contracts has been secured by European firms. As regards the erection of buildings, as distinguished from other works, the Company will be in the favourable position of being able to complete them from basement to roof, including their equipment throughout with electrical and sanitary appliances ; thus the profits on minor contracts can be secured to the Company. There is a great demand for small residential houses in Cairo and Alexandria, and a wide field is open to the Company to erect small houses in suitable localities, according to the plans and requirements of purchasers, and to have the cost of erection secured by Mortgages payable in instalments, with the usual interest there on, extending over a period to suit the convenience of clients.

The Company will in the first instance acquire and amalgamate the businesses carried on by the well-known firms of Engineers, Contractors and Builders, Messrs. McClure and Dorling, of Alexandria, and Messrs. G L. Pezzi and Co„ of Cairo and Alexandria. Both firms are highly respected, and have been entrusted with numerous important contracts by—amongst others—the Egyptian Government, H. H. The Khedive, the British Govern¬ment, the Egyptian State Railways Administration, the Prisons Department, the Quarantine Board, the British Schools, the Alexandria Water Company, etc. etc.

Messrs. G. L. Pezzi and Co., who have been established since 1865, in addition to their business as Contractors and Builders, canty on the lucrative business of supplying the building trade with paints, papers, and other building materials and requisite.

The immediate vendors to and promoters of the Company are Messrs. Barc’ay, Hicks and Co., of Cairo (hereinafter called “the Vendors”), who have agreed to acquire the said businesses from their respective proprietors with a view to the re-sale thereof to the Company at a profit, the particular of which appear from the statements hereinafter contained. The proprietors, Mr. T. McClure, Mr. S. Dorling and Mr. G. L. Pezzi who will be the first Managing Directors of the Company, show their confidence in the Company’s future, not only by taking six-sevenths of their proportion of the purchase price, other than the valuation of the stock and plant, entirely in fully paid shares, but they have also agreed, by the undermentioned Agreements (4) and (5) that during the first five years their salaries as Managing Directors shall not be payable in any year in which the Company shall not have earned profits sufficient to pay a dividend of 7 per cent, on the initial paid-up hospital, and have further agreed to retain a holding of 10 000 shares during their term of office, and to deposit the certificates of such shares with the Company.

Both businesses will be taken over by the Company as going concerns as from the 1st day of October, 1905, and the Company will have the benefit of all profit realized from that date. The property to be transferred to the Company will include, besides the goodwills of the two businesses, the benefit of all pending contracts, the benefit of the existing agreements for the business premises, the book debts from the 1st October, 1905, and the office furniture, fixtures and fittings.

The purchase price for the sale of the said goodwills, the pending contracts, the agreements for tenancy of the business premises, book debts, office furniture, fixtures and fittings has been fixed by the under-mentioned Agreement 1) at £10,000. The stock-in-trade, plant and appliances will be purchased at a valuation. The Vendors have agreed to pay the preliminary expenses of the Company down to the first general allotment of shares other than Brokerage, stamps on Share Warrants, and stamp duty on the Sale Agreement. Such preliminary expenses are estimated at £2,500. The value of the goodwills is fixed at £30 000. The Vendors have also agreed in consideration of the further payment of £6,000 in cash to subscribe or procure subscriptions for 75,000 shares in the Company ; 12,0 00 of these shares have been subscribed for by the Memorandum of Association. The laid amounts payable to the Vendors, namely £46,000 altogether, will be paid and satisfied as to £25,000 by the allotment of 25,000 shares and the balance of £21,000 in cash.

div.head: Management
div.p: The Company will have the advantage of the expert services of Mr. Thomas McClure, Mr. Stanley Darling and Mr. G. L Pezzi. who have consented to act as Managing Directors for a period of five years at a salary of £700 per annum each, payable only as above stated, after profits have been oarnef sufficient to pay a dividend of 7 per cent off the original capital of the Company. Messrs. McClure, Darling and Pezzi have all been in Egypt a great number of years during which time they have been engaged in engineering and building contracts of all kinds, and have acquired an exceptional knowledge of the peculiar and special requirements of the engineering and building industry of that country.

div.head: The Articles of Association contains the following Provisions--
div.p: “ 92 —The remuneration of each of the first Managing Directors shall be a fixed salary at the rate of £$540 a year, payable after profits sufficient to provide a dividend of 7 percent on the initial capital shall have been earned in such year. The remuneration if each Director (other that the first Managing Director) shall be at the rate of £200 a year. In addition to the remuneration aforesaid, each of the first Managing Directors and the Directors (if any) appointed by then in pursuance of the last preceding article shall receive by way of further remuneration a earn sum equal to 5 percent, on the profits certified by the Auditors of the Company to have to been made in each year in excess of a sum sufficient to provide a Dividend of 7 percent. upon the amount. paid up or credited as paid up in the share Capital for the time being, without making any provision for a Reserve Pond. In addition to the aforesaid remuneration each Director shall also receive such father sum (if any) as the Company in General Meeting may from time to time determine.’’

" 105.—The remuneration of a Managing Director appointed by the Directors shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors, and may be by way of salary or commission, or participation in profits; or by any or all of these modes."

“ 117.—If any Director, being willing, shall becalled upon to perform extra service, or to make any special exertions in going or residing abroad; or otherwise, for any of the purposes of the Company, or acts as trustee for the Company or its Debenture Holders and shall do so, the Company may remunerate such Director, either by a fixed sum or by a percentage of profits or otherwise, as may be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition to or in substitution for his remuneration above provided." The following Contracts have been entered into : —

(1) An Agreement dated the seventeenth day of February, 1906, between Messrs. Barclay. Hicks and Co., of Cairo, Egypt, herein aid thereinafter, called “the Vendors" of the one part and the Company of the other part, whereby the Vendors agree to sell to the Companv for the consideration before mentioned (a) and (t) the Goodwills of the businesses of Messrs. McClure and Dorling and of Mr. G. L. Pezzi; (c) the agreement* for the premises at Rue Mosque Attarine, and in St. David’s Buildings, Rue Cherif Pachs, at Alexandria, and at 8, Rue Abdin, at Cairo ; (d) the office furniture, fixtures and fittings; (e) the benefit of alt pending contracts ; and (J)all book and other debts from 1st October, 1905 ; and to sell at a valuation the stock-in-trade, plant and appliances. By snob agree¬ment the Vendors agree to pay the before mentioned preliminary excesses, and for the consideration herein before mentioned guarantee subscriptions for 76,000 shares.

(2) An Agreement dated the fourteenth day of February, $190, between Thomas McClure and Stanley Dorling of the one part and the Vendors of the other part whereby Messrs. McClure and Dorling agree to sell to the Vendors the goodwill of their business, pending contracts, book debts, agreement for office premises, and the office furniture fittings and fixtures as from 1st October, 1905, for the sum of £18 0 0, to be paid and satisfied as to the £ 14,000 by the allotment or transfer of 14,000 tally paid-up Share in the Company and as to the balance of £4,000 in Cash. And the Agreement also provides for the sale of the stock-in-trade, plant and appliances at a valuation.

(3) An Agreement dated the fourteenth day of February, 1905, between G. L. Pezzi agrees to sell to the Vendors the goodwill of the businesses, pending contracts, book debts, agreements for business premises, and the office furniture, fittings and fixtures, as from 1st October, 1905, for the sum of £10,000, to be satisfied wholly in fully paid Shares of the Company, and the Agreement also provides for the sale if the stock-in-trade, plant and appliances at a valuation.
The purchase price payable under each of the Agreements (2) and (3) will be pro¬vided out of the purchase consideration to be paid by the Company under Agreement (1).

(4.) An Agreement dated the seventeenth day of February, 1906, between the Company and Thomas McClure and Stanley Dorling providing for the appointment of the said T. McClure and S. Dorling as two of the first Managing Directors of the Company for a period of 5 years from the date thereof at a salary of £700 per annum each, payable only after profits sufficient to pay a dividend of 7 percent have been earned. And by the Agreement, Mr. T. McClure and Mr. S. Dorling agree to retain during the said period 5,000 shares of the Company, and to deposit the certificate for such shares with the Company.

(5.) An Agreement similar to the last-mentioned Agreement 4, dated the seven¬teenth day of February, 1906. between the Company and G. L. Pezzi, providing for his appointment as a Managing Director for the like term at the same salary payable in the same events, and for his retaining 5,000 shares, and depositing the certificate thereof with the Company.

Of the Directors, Messrs. T. McClure and S. Dorling are each interested to the extent of one half in this purchase price (including valuation money) payable under the above Agreement (2); and Mr. George Nungovich and Mr., M. Summers have agreed to subscriber procure subscriptions for l0,000 shares and 5,000 Shares respectively, and each will receive a commission of five percent, on the said number of Shares, which will be paid by the Vendors out of the £6,000 commission mentioned in the above Agreement (1). The Agreements providing for such payment are made with the Vendors, and are dated the 15th February, 1906.

The minimum subscription has been fixed by the articles at 15 percent, of the shares offered for subscription, but the amount on which the Directors will proceed to allotment is £75,000, the subscription of which has been guaranteed, as above stated.
By the Articles the Directors have power to increase that capital of the Company by a resolution of the Board to £200,000.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, which forms part of this Prospectus, is endorsed hereon.
The Company will pay to Bankers and Brokers a brokerage of 6d. per share on all share applied for by the public and allotted on applications bearing Bankers' or Brokers’ stamps.

Applications for Shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with change for the amount payable on application to the Company’s Bankers. If no allotment is made, the Application Money will be returned in full, and where the number of Shared allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in relationship to the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the Applicant.
Failure to pay any installment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.

The above mentioned Contracts, or copies thereof, together with a print of the Company’s Memorandum and Articles of Association, may be inspected at the Offices of the Company in Cairo, and of the Solicitor in Alexandria.
Copier of the Prospectus and Application Forms can be obtained at the said Offices of the Company and Solicitor.

div.head: Sport and Play. Football. Cairo Shield Final Tie. Royal Inniskillings King's Royal Riple Corps
div.p: The above well known rivals met on Satur¬day week to decide who should hold the above shield for the season 1906. The ground was in the best of order as both teams entered the arena each confident of victory. The captains lined their men out in the following order : King's Royal Rifle Corps—goal, Pickervince ; backs, Swinbourne, Ventimore; halves, Craston Wilson and Bruke; forwards, Mitchell, Bicknell, Booth, Soouter and Ketterick. Royal Inniskilling Fosilier’—goal, Lieut. Vernon ; backs, Robinson and Reid ; halves, Millar, Walker, and Smyth ; forwards, Black, Hutton, Cun¬ningham, Greer and Walsh.

The Inniskillings won the spin of the coin and decided to defend the city goals. Booth started the ball rolling before 7,500 spectators. The Rifles got away in fine style but Smyth robbed Mitchell and play was transferred towards Pickervince, but Venimors cleared well Some give-and-take play now ensued until Bruke got away and gave to Soouter, who had a nice ran towards Vernon, but his parting shot went wide. On the kick off Black got possession and centered well and Cunningham gave the sphere to Greer, who rent in a fast shot across the goal month, where Black, who was lying handy, had no troubles in scoring the first goal for the inniskillings amid cheers.

On resuming the Rifles got on a fast ran, Booth giving his wing men plenty of chances, bat over-eagerness spoiled all attempts. Good play by Smyth brought play well down but Broke, who was playing a fine game, robbed Black and play was transferred toward" Vernon. The latter in saving conceded a corner which was sent behind. On the kick-off the Inniskillings got away, Cunningham having a shot at goal, but the custodian was in fine fettle and saved the situation. Play now took a turn towards Robinson and Company. The left wing of the K.R.R. were playing a fine game. Once or twice Ketterick had very hard lines, his shots, which were of the international order missing the poet by a hair's breadth. The Inniskillings now took play in hand. Black, getting away on a good run, sent across where Greer got possession and with a last shot he sent np the second goal. The ball had just been centered when Greer, accepting a golden opportunity, scored again. The Rifles now took play in hand and Vernon had to be on his best behaviour or a goal would have been scored. Each goal was visited in turn np and down the field, the pace being a hot one. The Inniskillings now scored again per Hutton. Nothing of importance occurred from this up to half time, the score reading :—
Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers ... 5 goals King’s Royal Rifle Corps Nil

After the usual interval and refreshments play was once more resumed. The start was a bit sensational as the Rifles bombarded the Inniskillings’ goal, and it was more by good look than guiding that Vernon kept a clean sheet. The Inniskillings now advanced per Cunningham, but they were forced to retire, Craston relieving and Burke got away and sent in a daily cutter to Vernon, who just managed to save. The Rifles bad hard lines in not (poring but their shots lacked the necessary aging.” Good only by Walker changed the scene of operations and play was around Pickervince and be had a few iho‘8 to deal with, one shot from Blaok being weh saved. Midfield play now followed until

After the usual interval and refreshments play was once more resumed. The start was a bit sensational as the Rifles bombarded the Inniskillings’ goal, and it was more by good look than guiding that Vernon kept a clean sheet. The Inniskillings now advanced per Cunningham, but they were forced to retire, Craston relieving and Burke got away and sent in a daily cutter to Vernon, who just managed to save. The Rifles bad hard lines in not (poring but their shots lacked the necessary aging.” Good only by Walker changed the scene of operations and play was around Pickervince and be had a few shows to deal with, one shot from Black being well saved. Midfield play now followed until Souter got away on his own centered well. Burke, receiving, gave Bicknell, who missed the post by inches. Play for a while was in favour of the Rifles, and it made Vernon look out for his p’s and q’s. Play now became some what slack, Cunningham introducing some tricky work. Hutton and Black were combining but Swainbourne was one too many for them. Time and again he robbed when all seemed lost. The Rifles forwards now showed some fine combination but score they could not do. They planted the ball everywhere except the proper place. The Inniskillings now wakened up and Walsh got away on a dashing run and centered well to Cunningham, who in turn gave to Black sent well across to goal mouth. Walsh, getting the sphere sent in as swift shot, but the custodian brought off a very clever save. The Inniskillings were pressing very hard when offense spoiled any chance they had. Both teams were completely fagged out. It was now mearing up to full time as the Rifle strove hard to score, Ketterick striking the upright in the attempt. The excitement was intense as Booth sent past. On the kick-off Greer got away on a nice run and dodging Wilson he gave to Walsh, who with a high a shot sent the ball into the left top corner of the net. With only two minutes to go the Rifles made one more attempt but it was useless ,, the ball finding the back of the net. Shortly after the referee’s whistle sounded for full time leaving the Inniskillings winners of the shields and one of the best contested matches ever seen in Cairo by the following score:
Royal Innisking Fosiliers… 5 goals King’s Royal Rifle Corpos …Nil

div.head: Polo In Cairo
div.p: The first tie of the Gordon Challenge Cap was played on Saturday before a large crowd of residents and visitors. The opposing sides were : THE TOURISTS MOSQUITOES 1. Mr. Paravioiui 1. Cant. Stockwell 2. Mr. Pickering 2. Mr. Gore Graham 3. Mr. de Frev lie 3. Capt. Bartlett Back, Co). Sparkes Back. Mr. Dudgeon

Umpire, Captain Rome. 1st Chukker.—The Mosquitoes were first on the ball, ran it down, and narrowly missed scoring, Bartlett hitting wide and losing a good chance. From the hit out the tourists worked the ball up the ground and Dudgeon, in trying to save, scored a subsidiary against his side. Counting. the Mosquitoes took the ball down the ground but Sparkes weaved wel1, the ball was worked back to the Mosquitoes’ goal and from a melee in front Paravicini put it through. Scrambling play ensued, though the Tourists continued to press and Pickering scored for them again. It was a sticky chukker in which the tourists did most of the pressing and scored 2 goals and 1 subsidiary to nil.

2nd Chnkker.—For the first half of this chukker the game was confined to the Tourists’ end, the Mosquitoes missing one or two chances of scoring. Bartlett, however, with a brilliant ran down the field, scored the fret goal for his side. The same player shortly afterwards made another fine ran bat hit wide with his last shot. Dudgeon cantered well with a near side shot and Sparkes, in trying to save, hit behind. From the resulting penalty Bartlett scored. It was another rather sticky chukker in which the Mosquitoes were better and scored 2 goals to nil.

3rd Chukker.—Pickering get away from the throw-in but glimpsed a chance of scoring. Give- and-take play followed, first one side then the other attacking. Bartlett, on a fast white pony, with a great run the whole length of the ground, locked like getting a certain goal, but the hall bumped and Sparkes cleared. The Tourists then attacked and from a hustle in front of the posts snickering scored with a very neat shot. The same player again scored short¬ly afterwards, putting the Tourists 2 goals ahead. Then came the best piece play of the day. Bartlett got on the ball near his own goal and brought it right down, well backed up by Graham and Stockwell, the latter finally scoring a good goal. This was and very much better chukker, of which the Tourists had slightly the better and scored 2 goals to 1.

4th Chukker.—With seven minutes to play the Mosquitoes were 1 goal and 1 subsidiary to the bad. They played up hard and looked like scoring, but Sparkes saved well. Up and down the ground the ball travelled. Dudgeon, in trying to meet the ball, let in de Freville, who however missed chance. Tune was finally called with no farther ad¬dition to the score, the Tourists winning a good, hard, even game by 4 goals 1 subsi¬diary to 3 goals.

For the winners Sparkes and de Freville were best, the former being very safe and his hitting true and clean. For the losers Bartlett WAS brilliant; his hitting WAS hard, sure and straight, he was beautifully mounted, and always on the ball.

div.head: Billards Soldiers Club Tournament
div.p: The final game in the above tournament, which has been in progress during the present month, was reached on Thursday, when teams representing the Royal Engineers and Sergeants of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers met to decide supremacy.

The R.E. team were favourites, bat the RI.F. team (who were unfortunate in losing one of their best players, ordered to Crete) made a determined fight, and gave the supporters of the R.E. team an anxious time, as at the close of the first three games, only fifteen points divided the teams, The last player of the R.E. team, however, won by another fifteen, thus making the R.E. team winners of the tournament by the narrow margin of 30 points.

The special prize of a championship billard match one, for the highest break, goes to Sergeant Major Lumsden, R.I.F. The play of Loe Cpl. Robinson, of the K.R. Rifles and Supper Berry of the R.E., during the tournament, was much admired.
Score: S.M. Lumsden 138 v Supper Berry 150 Sergt. Grace 142 v Fyfield 155 Gruerin 150 v Andrews 145 Power 135 Stevens 150 The games were carefully marked by Bondsman Soloman, 2nd Rifle Brigade.

div.head: Bekanntmachung
div.p: Jm liiesigen HandelregisteJ, Abt. B. ist unter No. 6 heute eingetragen worden : DEUTSCHE ORIENTBANK AKTIEN- GESELL8CHAFT, Zweigniederlassnng Alexandrian, mit dem Sitze in Berlin.

Gegenstand des Unternehmenfi : Betrieb von Bankgeschaften aller Art, ins- besondere die Forderung der Handelsbezieh- ungen zwischen Deutschland and dem Orient. Grundkapital : 1G 000 000 Mark. Vorstand :
1) Felix JUdell, Bankdirektor, Berlin,- 2) Sigmund Mosevius, Bankdirektor, Berlin 3) Paul Thomas, Bankdirektor, Berlin
Den Kaufleuten Samuel Ritscher und A. Zamoran : beide in Aloxandrien, ist Gesammt- prokura erteilt

Der Gesellschaftsvertrag ist am 3. Januar 1906 festgestellt. Nach ihm wird die Gesell- schaft vertreten von zwei ordentlichen oder zwei stellvertretenden Vorstandsmitgliedem oder je einem ordentlichen und stellvertre¬tenden Vorstandsmitgliede oder von einem ordentlichen oder stellvertretenden Vorstands¬mitgliede und einen Prokurisfcen oder von zwei Prokuristen gemeinschaftlich.

Als nicht einz atragen wird bekannt gemacht: Das Grundkapital zerfallt in 16 000 je auf den Namen und fiber 1000 M. lautende Aktien, die znm Nennbetrage ausgegeben werden. Es wird in vier Serien eingeteilt, eine jede umfasst viertaosend Stfick Aktien. Auf jede Aktie sind bei Errichtnng der Gesellschaft 25 % eingezahlt; weitere Einzahlungen sind bis zur Vollzahlung auf die Serie 1 und sodann der Reihe nach auf die fibrigen anfeinanderfolgenden Serien einzufordern. div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.
PICTURE POST CARDS
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series Is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: To Our Visitors
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompnaying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care had been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered . To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in MArch it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weathet in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving is Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the continent of Europe.

They are as follows:- The long sea routes -- from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton, London or Liverpool--occupy abiut 14 days. The short ones are as follows:-- Port Said or Alexandria to Bridinsi: 3 days Alexnadria to Messina: 3 " Port Said or ALexandria to Marseilles 5" Alexandria to Venice and Trieste 4" Alexanria to Naples 3" Port Said to Genoa 5 " Alexandria to Constantinople 4" Alexandria to Pirricus 2" Port Said to Gibraltar 7"

The steamers, of the P. and O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Mesageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest in that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). Taht to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line had also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. and O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at afixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great lines arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships ahve enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed . They are called the "Ferry boats, having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. if you are going straight through to ENgland you will find the train waiting at Brinidisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: Hotels En Route; Syracuse Grand Hotel
div.note: Piazza Mazzini, Syracuse (Sicily). Best Hotel in the Town.

div.head: SICILY
div.p: The direct route is by the FlorioRubatiino Co.'s steamers which ahve leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which alight and, the druve up Taormina is most delightful, occuping about one hour. In and around the rown is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek Origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, ROman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history , having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413 , and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain-- his tomb is to be seen. the cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple, PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Sarcenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giavanna degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral Musuem, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and ROyal Park are also worth a visit.
The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10nhours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it wihtout wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay--Castellamare and Sorrento {you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surround country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Casino is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in FLorence, whislt the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 85 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distnace of four miles. The most deligthful execrusion outside FLorence is that to Vallombroza, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view/

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near PISA and on the main line from ROme to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house beteen Egypt and England, and where livin is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

GENOA (LA SUPERBA)-- The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature--warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are constant delight to thousands of travellars who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principle attraction, with its beautiful windows illustratiing the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGIORE, a reowned health resort on account if its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
